title: Over 100 MPs urge Barclays to reverse decision on Post Office cash
text:
Barclays' move to stop customers accessing cash from Post Office branches has been blasted by more than 100 MPs from across the political spectrum.

Led by Labour MP Chris Elmore, politicians have written a letter to the bank's boss, Jes Staley, urging him to reverse the decision to prevent people from taking cash out at Post Office branches from 8 January 2020.

The politicians want Barclays to end the 'cash crisis', amid fears the decision will hit the vulnerable, elderly and those in rural communities hardest.

Fighting back: Barclays' move to stop customers accessing cash from Post Office branches has been blasted by over 100 MPs

Campaigners have accused Barclays of abandoning its customers and denying them crucial access to their money at a time when bank branch closure rates are soaring.

Between January 2015 and August this year, Barclays closed over 480 branches up and down the country.

Last year, there were around 15million cash withdrawals made by Barclays customers through the Post Office.

Business secretary Andrea Leadsom has already urged Barclays to consider reversing its decision.

Meanwhile, the Treasury Committee has previously said Barclays' move is 'hugely disappointing', adding that 'the use of cash cannot be left to wither on the vine.'

The letter from MPs to Staley today said: 'This change will only add to the cash crisis many of the most vulnerable and elderly in our communities are currently facing.

'We would strongly urge you to reverse this decision to prevent your customers - and our constituents - from being left behind in the wake of the banking sector's digitisation.'

The letter says Barclays' decision 'sends a message - rightly or wrongly - that those who cannot properly access the digital economy will have the carpet dragged from under their feet as our high street banks continue to abandon the communities that have sustained them for decades.'

In the letter, the MPs offer to meet Staley to discuss their concerns in person, adding: 'We look forward to hearing from you as a matter of urgency.'

📺 WATCH: This afternoon, I raised this with @CommonsLeader and called on him to ask Treasury Ministers to address this issue.



It's essential that the UK Government does all it can to ensure communities across our country maintain free #AccessToCash. pic.twitter.com/YGSMOIC1Ti — Chris Elmore MP (@CPJElmore) October 17, 2019

Branch closures: Between January 2015 and August this year, Barclays closed over 480 branches up and down the country

Calling for reversal: Business secretary Andrea Leadsom has already urged Barclays to consider reversing its decision

Elmore said: 'We recognise that our economy is becoming inherently digital but that mustn't mean we leave behind those who aren't able to make this transition overnight.

'Stripping away the already minute level of banking services available on our high streets lets down those communities who have supported these banks for decades."

In response to the letter, a Barclays spokeswoman said: 'We acknowledge receipt of the letter from Chris Elmore MP, and we are working with him and other MPs to confirm our new commitments that will ensure that no one will be left without access to cash.'

The fightback against Barclays' Post Office cash decision is ramping up.

Federation of Small Businesses national chairman Mike Cherry said: 'This cross-party group of MPs is absolutely right to ask Barclays to think again.

'The Post Office plays a vital role in enabling access to cash for small business owners and their customers, particularly in remote areas that have been disproportionately hit by bank branch and ATM closures.

'That role can only continue if the banks get behind it; 27 already have, Barclays would do well to follow their lead.'

Meanwhile, Gareth Shaw, head of money at consumer group, Which?, said: 'Barclays has shown real disregard to the needs of its customers through its reckless move to cease cash withdrawals from the Post Office.

'MPs are right to challenge this ill-conceived decision that risks leaving many of their constituents facing an uphill struggle just to access the cash they need.

'It's clear the broken cash landscape is being further damaged by industry's approach, which is why we're calling on the government to urgently intervene with legislation that protects cash for as long as it is needed.'

The Payment Systems Regulator has said it will be 'closely monitoring' the steps Barclays plans to take.

But, speaking last week, Adam Rowse, managing director of branch-based banking at Barclays, said: 'By maintaining last-in-town or remote branches over the next two years, and working with the community, we hope to increase demand and keep these branches viable.

'We also recognise that there are opportunities to support customers with access to cash where there is no branch or ATM nearby.

'We are launching a cashback offering working with merchants to give customers access to cash over the counter.'

Barclays, which made a £3.5billion profit last year and dished out £3.4million in pay to boss Staley last year, has denied its decision is to do with cost-cutting and claims it is investing in schemes to help its customers access their money more easily.
